Retail's Risky AI Commerce Bet: Data Control and Market Share at Stake

Google, Etsy, Wayfair ë“±ì˜ ì£¼ìš” ì†Œë§¤ì—…ì²´ë“¤ì´ ì—ì´ì „íŠ¸ AI ìƒê±°ë˜ì— íˆ¬ìí•˜ë©´ì„œ ë°ì´í„° ì†Œìœ ê¶Œ ìƒì‹¤ì˜ ìœ„í—˜ì— ì§ë©´í•˜ê³  ìˆë‹¤. ëŒ€í˜• ê¸°ìˆ  í”Œë«í¼ì´ ì‡¼í•‘ ê²½í—˜ì„ ì¤‘ê°œí•˜ë©´ì„œ ì†Œë§¤ì—…ì²´ë“¤ì€ ê³ ê° ë°ì´í„°ì™€ ì§ì ‘ì ì¸ ê´€ê³„ì— ëŒ€í•œ ì œì–´ë ¥ì„ ìƒì„ ê°€ëŠ¥ì„±ì´ ë†’ë‹¤. ì´ëŸ¬í•œ ê²½í–¥ì€ ì†Œë§¤ì—…ì²´ì˜ ë§ˆì§„ìœ¨ ê°ì†Œì™€ ì¥ê¸°ì  ê²½ìŸë ¥ ì•½í™”ë¡œ ì´ì–´ì§ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤.
Major retailers including Google, Etsy, and Wayfair are facing significant risks of losing data control as they invest heavily in agentic AI commerce. As large tech platforms mediate the shopping experience, retailers risk ceding control of customer data and direct relationships. This shift threatens retailer margins and long-term competitive positioning in an AI-driven commerce landscape.
  • Retailers risk losing customer data ownership and direct relationships to tech platforms mediating agentic commerce
  • Data dependency on third-party platforms could reduce margins and limit competitive differentiation
  • D2C brands and retailers should invest in proprietary AI agents to maintain customer relationship control

D2C brands must prioritize building proprietary AI shopping experiences or strengthen owned-channel strategies. commercetools identifies 7 key AI trends reshaping agentic commerce in 2026, including multimodal AI interactions, real-time inventory orchestration, and the maturation of composable commerce architectures. These trends enable retailers to deliver faster, more personalized shopping experiences while fundamentally transforming retail operations. Accelerating adoption of composable architectures allows enterprises to leverage standardized API-based integrations and flexible technology stacks.
  • Composable commerce architectures enable flexible, modular deployment of agentic AI capabilities
  • Multimodal AI interactions and real-time inventory orchestration are becoming table-stakes for customer experience
  • API-standardization is driving interoperability and reducing vendor lock-in in agentic commerce ecosystems

eMarketer's latest analysis reveals that while AI shopping tools are gaining consumer traction, retailer pushback threatens to slow market growth. Concerns about data ownership, margin compression, and loss of customer relationship control are delaying adoption among traditional retailers. 2026 market growth may fall short of earlier predictions, with technology integration and regulatory challenges emerging as key bottlenecks.
  • Consumer demand for AI shopping tools is strong, but retailer resistance to data loss and margin compression is slowing adoption
  • First-mover D2C brands can establish customer preference for their agentic experiences before large retailers catch up
  • Regulatory clarity on data privacy and AI transparency may emerge as a competitive differentiator

Microsoft positions agentic commerce as the new paradigm for retail entry points, showcasing real-world Copilot-powered shopping experiences already in deployment. Klaviyo identifies 8 critical trends in marketing automation for 2026, centering on AI-driven personalization, privacy compliance, and zero-party data activation. Advanced segmentation (behavioral and predictive) and real-time personalization are becoming standard, while regulatory compliance automation (GDPR, CCPA) is emerging as a competitive differentiator. Predictive analytics for lifetime value optimization is becoming essential to customer retention strategies.
  • AI-powered behavioral segmentation and predictive personalization are becoming baseline expectations for competitive marketing automation
  • Privacy compliance automation is now a strategic advantage; brands that automate GDPR/CCPA compliance gain operational efficiency
  • Zero-party data activation through progressive profiling and first-party data enrichment drives superior customer lifetime value

Marketing Dive forecasts that 2026 will be characterized by AI-driven polarity in marketing performance. The gap between AI-effective companies and laggards will widen dramatically, with competitive advantage determined in personalization, content generation, and customer segmentation. Regulatory tightening and privacy requirements will fundamentally reshape how data-driven marketing operates.
  • AI will create winners and losers in marketing; laggards in AI adoption face competitive extinction
  • Zero-party data collection and privacy-first personalization will become essential competitive advantages
  • Content generation via AI will become commoditized, shifting competition to personalization and context relevance

Google Makes Etsy and Wayfair Items Shoppable Within Agentic AI Search

GoogleëŠ” ìì‹ ì˜ ì—ì´ì „íŠ¸ AI ê²€ìƒ‰ ì¸í„°í˜ì´ìŠ¤ ë‚´ì—ì„œ Etsyì™€ Wayfairì˜ ìƒí’ˆì„ ì§ì ‘ êµ¬ë§¤í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë„ë¡ í†µí•©í–ˆë‹¤. ì´ëŠ” Googleì˜ Universal Commerce Platform(UCP)ì˜ ë˜ ë‹¤ë¥¸ í™•ì¥ìœ¼ë¡œ, ê³ ê°ì´ ê²€ìƒ‰ ê²°ê³¼ í˜ì´ì§€ì—ì„œ ë²—ì–´ë‚˜ì§€ ì•Šê³ ë„ ìƒí’ˆì„ ë°œê²¬í•˜ê³  êµ¬ë§¤í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë„ë¡ í•œë‹¤. ì´ëŠ” Etsyì™€ Wayfairì—ê²ŒëŠ” ì¶”ê°€ íŠ¸ë˜í”½ì„ ê°€ì ¸ì˜¤ì§€ë§Œ, ê³ ê° ë°ì´í„°ì™€ ê´€ê³„ì—ì„œì˜ í†µì œë ¥ ì†ì‹¤ì€ ë¶ˆê°€í”¼í•˜ë‹¤.
Google has integrated Etsy and Wayfair products directly into its agentic AI search interface, making items purchasable without leaving the search experience. This expansion of Google's Universal Commerce Platform (UCP) enables customers to discover and buy products while staying within the Google ecosystem. While this drives traffic to Etsy and Wayfair, it furthers their dependence on Google for customer access and data visibility.
  • Google's agentic shopping integration is expanding to more retailers and marketplaces, deepening customer lifecycle dependency on Google
  • Marketplace sellers and retailers gain traffic visibility but lose customer data ownership and retention control
  • D2C brands must balance platform visibility with customer relationship building in owned channels
ğŸ’¡ So What
D2C ë¸Œëœë“œë“¤ì€ Google UCPì™€ì˜ í†µí•©ì„ ì ê·¹ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ì¶”ì§„í•´ì•¼ í•˜ì§€ë§Œ, ë™ì‹œì— ê³ ê°ì„ ìì‹ ì˜ ì†Œìœ  ì±„ë„ë¡œ ìœ ë„í•˜ëŠ” ì „ëµì„ ë³‘í–‰í•´ì•¼ í•œë‹¤. Googleì„ ì£¼ìš” ê³ ê° ë°œê²¬ ê²½ë¡œë¡œë§Œ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ê³ , ì¬êµ¬ë§¤ì™€ ì¶©ì„±ë„ êµ¬ì¶•ì€ ìì²´ ì±„ë„ì—ì„œ í•´ì•¼ í•œë‹¤.

The Biggest AI Marketing Trends for 2026

WordStreamì˜ ë¶„ì„ì— ë”°ë¥´ë©´, 2026ë…„ AI ë§ˆì¼€íŒ…ì˜ ê°€ì¥ í° íŠ¸ë Œë“œëŠ” AI Overviews í™•ì‚°, ê²€ìƒ‰ì—”ì§„ ìµœì í™”ì˜ ì§„í™”(AEO - Agentic Engine Optimization), ê·¸ë¦¬ê³  ëŒ€ê·œëª¨ AI ê¸°ë°˜ ì½˜í…ì¸  ìƒì„±ì´ë‹¤. Googleì˜ AI Overviewsê°€ ìœ ê¸°ì  ê²€ìƒ‰ íŠ¸ë˜í”½ì„ ê°ì†Œì‹œí‚¤ë©´ì„œ, ë§ˆì¼€íŒ… ì „ëµì´ í‚¤ì›Œë“œ ìµœì í™”ì—ì„œ ì—ì´ì „íŠ¸ AIì— ìµœì í™”ëœ ì½˜í…ì¸ ë¡œ ì´ë™í•˜ê³  ìˆë‹¤. ë˜í•œ ë™ì˜ìƒ, ì´ë¯¸ì§€, ì¸í„°ë™í‹°ë¸Œ ì½˜í…ì¸  ìƒì„±ì´ AIë¡œ ìë™í™”ë˜ë©´ì„œ ì½˜í…ì¸  ìƒì‚° ë¹„ìš©ì´ ê¸‰ê²©íˆ ê°ì†Œí•œë‹¤.
WordStream identifies the biggest AI marketing trends for 2026: proliferation of AI Overviews, the evolution of search optimization into Agentic Engine Optimization (AEO), and large-scale AI-powered content generation. Google's AI Overviews are reducing organic search traffic to publishers, forcing marketing strategies to shift from keyword optimization to content optimized for agentic AI systems. Video, image, and interactive content generation are becoming increasingly automated via AI, dramatically reducing content production costs.
  • AI Overviews and agentic search are cannibalizing traditional organic search traffic; content strategies must adapt
  • Agentic Engine Optimization (AEO) is becoming more important than traditional SEO for organic visibility
  • AI-powered content generation is reducing content production costs, but quality and brand differentiation require human curation
ğŸ’¡ So What
D2C ë§ˆì¼€íŒ…íŒ€ë“¤ì€ ì „í†µ SEO íˆ¬ìë¥¼ ì ì§„ì ìœ¼ë¡œ AEO(ì—ì´ì „íŠ¸ ì—”ì§„ ìµœì í™”)ë¡œ ì „í™˜í•´ì•¼ í•œë‹¤. ë˜í•œ AI ë„êµ¬(ChatGPT, Claude, Midjourney)ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì½˜í…ì¸  ì œì‘ ì†ë„ë¥¼ ë†’ì´ê³  ë¹„ìš©ì„ ë‚®ì¶°ì•¼ í•œë‹¤. ë™ì‹œì— AI ìƒì„± ì½˜í…ì¸ ì˜ í’ˆì§ˆ ê´€ë¦¬ì™€ ë¸Œëœë“œ ë³´ì´ìŠ¤ ìœ ì§€ì— ì£¼ì˜í•´ì•¼ í•œë‹¤.
D2C marketing teams should gradually shift SEO investment toward AEO (Agentic Engine Optimization). Leverage AI tools (ChatGPT, Claude, Midjourney) to increase content production velocity and reduce costs. Simultaneously, maintain rigorous quality control and brand voice consistency to ensure AI-generated content meets brand standards.

ğŸ† This Week's Top 5 Trends

1. Agentic Commerce Platform War Heats Up

Google rolled out its Universal Commerce Protocol (UCP) making Etsy and Wayfair products purchasable directly within AI search. Criteo launched its MCP-based Agentic Commerce Recommendation Service. Microsoft Copilot Checkout went live in the US, marking the transition from proof-of-concept to real transactions.

Sources:

  • Google makes Etsy and Wayfair items shoppable within agentic AI search
  • Criteo Introduces Agentic Commerce Recommendation Service
  • Microsoft: Agentic Commerce Is the New Front Door

ğŸ’¡ So What for D2C: D2C brands must ensure products are "discoverable" by AI agents through structured data (schema, reviews, pricing). Early participation in UCP/MCP protocols creates traffic acquisition opportunities in the AI era.

2. Retailer Data Sovereignty Crisis

Concerns grow that exposing products on AI platforms transfers control of customer data and purchase journeys to the platforms. Shopify and Amazon have begun restricting external AI agents, and Walmart added guidelines blocking agent checkout access. Deloitte found 81% of retail executives expect generative AI to weaken brand loyalty.

Sources:

  • Retail's risky AI commerce bet
  • AI shopping tools gain traction, but retailer pushback

ğŸ’¡ So What for D2C: Strengthening 1st-party data channels (owned apps, membership, newsletters) is the core survival strategy. Use AI platforms for "discovery" only; conversion and repurchase should happen on owned channels.

3. AI Marketing Automation â€” Personalization vs Privacy

87% of brands plan to increase personalization investment in 2026, but few execute cross-channel personalization. EU and Apple regulatory tightening makes zero-party data strategy essential. The gap between "data-rich brands and guessing brands" will be the defining divide of 2026.

Sources:

  • 8 Marketing Automation Trends for 2026
  • 9 marketing predictions for 2026

ğŸ’¡ So What for D2C: Actively collect zero-party data (quizzes, preference centers, reviews) and integrate with CDP to achieve "data-driven personalization, not guesswork."

4. Post-NRF 2026: SAP & Microsoft Enterprise AI Solutions

SAP's MCP-based Storefront server and Order Reliability Agent, plus Microsoft's Copilot Checkout, have launched as concrete products. With 68% of retailers planning agentic AI deployment within 12-24 months, enterprise AI has moved from "strategic discussion" to "implementation phase."

Sources:

  • NRF 2026: SAP Builds AI Into the Core of Retail
  • Microsoft propels retail forward with agentic AI

ğŸ’¡ So What for D2C: Assess whether existing ERP/commerce stacks are AI-ready and consider composable commerce architecture. Agentic AI ROI appears fastest in order management, inventory, and CX.

5. Rise of AEO (AI Engine Optimization)

Beyond traditional SEO, AEO â€” ensuring visibility in AI search engines (ChatGPT, Gemini, Perplexity) â€” has emerged as an essential marketing capability. Structured data and content quality now determine whether brands get recommended by AI.

Sources:

  • The Biggest AI Marketing Trends for 2026
  • Agentic Shopping: How AI Is Transforming Ecommerce

ğŸ’¡ So What for D2C: Expand SEO teams into AEO. Optimizing product page structured data (Schema.org), FAQs, and review data for AI comprehension is the top D2C marketing priority for 2026.

ğŸ“ˆ This Week's Observations: Risks & Opportunities

  1. Risk â€” Deepening Platform Dependency: As native checkout expands across Google/Microsoft/OpenAI, D2C direct traffic may further decline. Relying solely on AI platforms without preparation risks losing both margins and data.

  2. Opportunity â€” First-mover Advantage: Few D2C brands are investing in AI agent optimization yet. Investing in structured data and AEO now can secure competitive advantage.

  3. Observation â€” The Human Branding Paradox: As AI automates every channel, consumers are increasingly drawn to "human-made" authenticity. Balancing AI efficiency with human genuineness will be the core brand strategy challenge of 2026.

ğŸ“– Monthly Deep DiveMonthly Deep Dive

ë¦¬ì„œì¹˜ ê¸°ë°˜ ê¹Šì´ ìˆëŠ” ë¶„ì„ Research-based in-depth analysis

Monthly Deep Dive: Agentic Commerce ì›ë…„ â€” D2Cê°€ ì•Œì•„ì•¼ í•  5ê°€ì§€ ì „ëµì  ì‹œì‚¬ì  Monthly Deep Dive: The Year of Agentic Commerce â€” 5 Strategic Implications for D2C

ğŸ“– 2026ë…„ 2ì›” Monthly Deep Dive

ì´ë‹¬ì˜ ë¬¸ì¥ (Quote of the Month)

"The gap in 2026 won't be between brands using AI and brands not using AI. It'll be between brands with rich customer data and brands guessing at what their customers want." â€” StackAdapt Personalization Report 2026

í•µì‹¬ ë³´ê³ ì„œ ìš”ì•½

1. McKinsey: Agentic Commerceì˜ ì¡° ë‹¨ìœ„ ì‹œì¥ ì „ë§

í•µì‹¬ í¬ì¸íŠ¸:

  • 2030ë…„ê¹Œì§€ ë¯¸êµ­ B2C ë¦¬í…Œì¼ì—ì„œ AI ì—ì´ì „íŠ¸ê°€ ì¤‘ê°œí•˜ëŠ” ê±°ë˜ê°€ ìµœëŒ€ 1ì¡° ë‹¬ëŸ¬ì— ë‹¬í•  ì „ë§
  • ê¸€ë¡œë²Œ ê·œëª¨ë¡œëŠ” 3~5ì¡° ë‹¬ëŸ¬ ê·œëª¨ë¡œ í™•ì¥ ê°€ëŠ¥

ğŸ“– February 2026 Monthly Deep Dive

Quote of the Month

"The gap in 2026 won't be between brands using AI and brands not using AI. It'll be between brands with rich customer data and brands guessing at what their customers want." â€” StackAdapt Personalization Report 2026

Key Report Summaries

1. McKinsey: The Trillion-Dollar Agentic Commerce Market Outlook

Key Takeaways:

  • AI agents are projected to mediate up to $1 trillion in US B2C retail transactions by 2030
  • Global scale could expand to $3-5 trillion
  • Currently (2026) represents 1.5% of total ecommerce (~$20.9 billion), but is growing 4x year-over-year

Implications for D2C:

  • Agentic commerce has shifted from "experiment" to "strategic investment area"
  • Even at the $20.9 billion scale, early-entry brands can capture significant AI recommendation share within their category

ğŸ“„ Source: McKinsey â€” "Agentic commerce could orchestrate $1T in US retail" | Download Report (PDF)

2. Deloitte 2026 Retail Industry Global Outlook

Key Takeaways:

  • 81% of retail executives expect generative AI to weaken brand loyalty by 2027
  • As AI agents auto-compare pricing, reviews, and return policies, "price transparency" reaches maximum
  • 68% of retailers plan agentic AI deployment within 12-24 months

Implications for D2C:

  • Price alone cannot compete in the AI agent era â€” differentiation through brand story, community, and exclusive products is essential
  • Loyalty programs require redesign to provide structured benefits that AI agents can "understand"

ğŸ“„ Source: Deloitte â€” 2026 Retail Industry Outlook | Download Report (PDF)

3. Forrester: One-Quarter of Shoppers to Use Specialty Retail Chatbots

Key Takeaways:

  • 25% of consumers are expected to use specialist retail chatbots in 2026
  • Agentic shopping assistants evolving beyond simple responses into "purchase guide" roles
  • Per Bain & Company, 30-45% of US consumers already use generative AI for product research

Implications for D2C:

  • Deploying AI chatbots/assistants on owned stores becomes a baseline competitive requirement
  • Integrating chatbot data into CRM/CDP enhances customer insights

ğŸ“„ Source: Forrester â€” 2026 Predictions: Commerce | View Research

4. Gartner: Enterprise AI Agents to Reach 40% Adoption

Key Takeaways:

  • By end of 2026, 40% of enterprise applications are projected to include task-specific AI agents
  • Retail technology spending reaches $388 billion, with AI investment growing 25% annually
  • 91% of retail leaders are investing in AI, with early adopters realizing 6x faster ROI

Implications for D2C:

  • Urgent: Evaluate AI agent deployment in operations (order management, inventory, customer service)
  • "AI-ready" infrastructure (API-first, composable architecture) is critical to resolving technical debt

ğŸ“„ Source: Gartner â€” Top Strategic Technology Trends 2026 | View Research

5. StackAdapt: Key Digital Marketing Personalization Trends

Key Takeaways:

  • 87% of brands plan to expand personalization investment, but execution remains early-stage
  • Data fragmentation, tool fragmentation, and measurement gaps are primary barriers to cross-channel personalization
  • The AdTech/MarTech convergence makes "identity-based real-time personalization" the 2026 priority

Implications for D2C:

  • CDP adoption/enhancement is foundational to personalization strategy
  • Systematize zero-party data collection (quizzes, preference centers) to ensure data quality for AI-driven personalization

ğŸ“„ Source: StackAdapt â€” Key Trends Shaping Digital Marketing Personalization | Download Report (PDF)

ğŸ¯ D2C Organization Action Items

  1. Establish Agentic Commerce Response Task Force: Form a cross-functional TF to ensure products are exposed and transactable on AI platforms (Google UCP, Microsoft Copilot Checkout, OpenAI Shopping) with technical and data readiness (Ownership: Commerce/IT/Data)

  2. Conduct Structured Data and AEO Audit: Ensure all product catalog Schema.org markup, review data, and price feeds are formatted for accurate AI agent reading (Ownership: Marketing/IT)

  3. Strengthen 1st-Party Data Strategy: Audit customer data leakage to AI platforms and reinforce direct collection channels via owned apps, membership programs, and newsletters (Ownership: CRM/Data)

  4. Deploy or Upgrade CDP: Select, implement, or audit existing CDP usage to resolve data fragmentation and enable cross-channel personalization (Ownership: Data/MarTech)

  5. Launch AI Chatbot PoC: Run AI shopping assistant pilot on owned store to measure conversion lift (Ownership: Commerce/CX)

  6. Redesign Loyalty Programs: Structure loyalty benefits so they are legible to AI agents and create differentiation when agents compare/recommend brands (Ownership: CRM/Strategy)

  7. Institutionalize Monthly AI Trend Reviews: Use AI Trend Hub to conduct monthly organization-wide briefings on latest developments and action items (Ownership: D2C Strategy)

ğŸŒ Regional Observations

AMER (Americas): The US is at the forefront of agentic commerce. Google, Microsoft, OpenAI, and Amazon all prioritize the US market, with payment infrastructure (Mastercard Agent Pay, Visa/Stripe agent frameworks) expanding US-first. D2C brands need immediate response in this market.

EMEA (Europe, Middle East, Africa): Stricter EU privacy regulations (including AI Act) are slowing agentic commerce adoption relative to the Americas. However, EMEA is pioneering zero-party data strategies in GDPR environments â€” D2C brands benefit from adopting EMEA's privacy-first approach as a global standard.

APAC (Asia Pacific): China's AI commerce ecosystem (Taobao AI, JD.com's JIMI agent) is developing independently. Southeast Asian platforms (Shopee, Lazada) are enhancing AI recommendation capabilities, while Japan and South Korea see AI shopping assistants emerging through LINE and Kakao. Regional platform strategies are essential for D2C success.
